ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Critical thinking needed in shaping innovation in government and society
- How ideas from one field can be applied to another - Strategies for effective stakeholder engagement - Structured thinking
Interesting understanding of ways in which government could be innovative but also the implications of that innovation

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One of the most disappointing classes I've had at Yale. Had a lot of promise but the requirements/expectations were unclear and constantly changing. I took this course because I thought we would be working for a client and the Professor indicated that while there would be no formal client the outcome would be similar. Instead, it was incredibly frustrating the entire semester. Braverman and Ted were nice, but the course was one of my least favorite at Yale.
Strengths - Pushes you to think hard - A great exposure on ways to approach difficult problems Weakness - Higher accountability for team work could be baked into the design of the course
The topic of assignment was hard to materialize right until the very end, maybe a bit more guidance at the beginning could be better

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, take it if interested in public sector and ways to improve it.
